instruction: Can multispectral fluorescence lifetime imaging microscopy (FLIM) be used as a superior method compared to traditional techniques for characterizing the autofluorescence lifetime (AFL) characteristics of coronary arteries and atheromas in this research?
Output: Yes, multispectral fluorescence lifetime imaging microscopy (FLIM) can be considered a superior method compared to traditional techniques for characterizing the autofluorescence lifetime (AFL) characteristics of coronary arteries and atheromas in this research. The study demonstrates that FLIM provides a wide field-of-view, high-resolution AFL imaging of frozen sections, allowing for detailed pixel-level investigation of the complex composition of coronary arteries and atheromas. FLIM was able to visualize and distinguish between different components of the arteries, such as tunica media, tunica adventitia, elastic laminas, smooth muscle cell-enriched fibrous plaque, lipid-rich core, and foamy macrophages, based on their distinct AFL spectra. Additionally, FLIM parameters showed a significant difference between proatherogenic components (lipids and foamy macrophages) and plaque-stabilizing components (collagen and smooth muscle cells). The study also demonstrated that FLIM can be used for automated, simultaneous visualization of key atherosclerotic components with high accuracy. This suggests that FLIM has the potential to be a valuable tool for efficiently evaluating ex vivo samples without the need for histological staining and analysis.
